Writing about the NBA as I see it from 5,000 miles away… For fans in the UK, without the American popular culture references none of us understand
Jul 17, 2016

You’re not the Warriors, you’re the Knicks, and there’s nothing wrong with that

The new-look Knicks aren’t ending New York’s 33-year wait for a championship in 2017, but they can put some smiles back on faces at the Garden

I CAN’T quite believe I’m saying this, but I really like what the Knicks have done this summer. Only one city can celebrate a championship next summer (and it’s not going to be New York), so they might as well enjoy the ride, right?

There was only one (maybe two) ways that the Knickerbockers were going to even come close to competing for a championship this season. If LeBron (who’s still a free agent, by the way) signed for the Knicks, or any other team in the East, they immediately become capable of reaching the Finals. But King James is staying in Cleveland. And if Kevin Durant hadn’t lost his appetite for a challenge and had instead been drawn to the bright lights of the Big Apple, then maybe the Knicks could’ve overthrown the King and his Cavaliers. The smart money would’ve still been on the champs though.

So, with no LeBron and no KD, there were plenty of directions the Knicks could have headed. Some will say that they completely missed their turn all together, but I say they should put their foot on the gas, not look back and enjoy the ride…

Firstly, the Derrick Rode trade is 100% a risk worth taking. What have the Knicks got to lose? Robin Lopez? The guy’s got funny hair, and an even funnier voice, oh and he sets really good screens, but seriously? To be in with even the slightest chance that you’re the team that ends up with a Rose something close to his pre-injury self, Phil Jackson should’ve, without hesitation, murdered Lopez if necessary and dealt with the ramifications later. Spend the rest of your life in prison? Fuck it. You’ve got the old D-Rose!

If it turns out that Rose just can’t do it anymore, he’s only got a year left on his contract anyway. Say thank you, goodbye and free up $21 million in cap space. If we’re ever going to find out what the youngest MVP in history has left in the tank, it’s going to be this year. I bet, given enough minutes, even Robert Sacre could muster up enough to be productive in a contract year.

Plus, what were the alternatives? Another year of Jose Calderon? Throwing $30 million a season at Mike Conley for the next five years? Linsanity Part Two? Matthew Dellavedova? (lol) As good as Conley is, that’s a lot of money, even after a cap spike, for a 28-year-old, not quite elite point guard, coming off an achilles injury. As for the rest, the less said, the better.

As soon as I heard about the Rose trade — well, after ten or fifteen minutes of thinking I might actually cry — I tweeted the following;

Whilst Dwight Howard and Hassan Whiteside were still on the market, it looked as though I could be woken from my ‘floor-spacing dream’ long before the conclusion. But Howard went home to Atlanta, Whiteside stayed in Miami and the Knicks signed a centre that might just be able to keep the ‘floor-spacing dream’ alive.

After nine seasons in Chicago, New York City’s own, Joakim Noah, was coming home. With a jump shot worse than mine, Noah’s not going to space the floor with his shooting. But his unique ability to step out of the paint and play point-centre could still open up driving and cutting lanes for Rose to go to work.

Other than getting Rose one-on-one drives to the basket, the Noah/Rose tandem could also benefit the Knicks by taking some defensive attention away from ‘Melo. And let’s not forget, Carmelo Anthony is still one of best scorers in NBA. Noah can draw opposition bigs out of the paint with the threat of his passing, Rose can’t be left alone to cut to the rim and Kristaps Porzingis and Courtney Lee are dangerous enough shooters not to be left open on the perimeter. (Lee, a really nice pick up from the Hornets, is a more than respectable career .384% three-point shooter. Which is actually a better average than ‘Melo) One-on-one, the list of players that can slow the 2013 scoring champ down is a short one. The list of players that can shut him down completely is still blank.

Finally, and perhaps most importantly to the Knicks’ hopes going forward, year two tends to be the year in which top young talents show what they can really do. Enter Porzingis. The 7'3" quick-footed, sweet-shooting Latvian has all the tools a big man needs to dominate the modern NBA.

If you’ve got another eight minutes to spare, watch the above video. To paraphrase the great Simon Cooper, “it says a lot of the things I want to say, but sort of better”.

If you watched it, then I think you’ll want to join me in thanking Drew Miller. If you couldn’t be arsed, I’ll summarise; Porzingis is really fucking good!

But even with the old D-Rose, this generation’s Ray Allen, the greatest scorer of all time, Dirk 2.0 and the best passing centre to ever grace the hardwood, the Knicks still aren’t winning a title this season. But what’s better, not winning a title and sucking? Or not winning a title and having a good time? Yeah. There are plenty of fans that aren’t going to enjoy this season (a.k.a. Kings fans), but with this group of players, Knicks fans shouldn’t be among them. Often it’s the journey that’s more enjoyable than the destination. This could be the start of something better for NYC basketball and if it is, Knicks fans, sit back and try to enjoy the “floor spacing dream”.
